comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: Mark-B At first I thought it was a medium or large format camera, as the original print was 13 1/2 x 10 1/2 inches, but since Lange took 5 photos of the woman (Florence Thompson) and her children in quick succession, she may well have been using a Leica. Lange told a fascinating story about this image, which was one of the last she took at the end of long hard winter. She was on her way home in the car. It was raining. A sign on the roadside announced the camp of the pea harvesters. According to Lange "I didn't want to remember that I'd seen it." She drove past, but could not put it out of her mind. A whole twenty miles later, Lange turned the car round: "I was following instinct, not reason." Back at the camp she saw the woman and her seven children. "I do not remember," Lange told Roy Stryker, "how I explained my presence or my camera to her, but I do remember she asked no questions. I took five shots, coming ever closer. I did not ask her name or history. She told me she was 32. She said that they had been living on frozen vegetables and birds that the children had killed. She had sold the tires on her car to buy food. There she sat in that lean-to tent with her children huddled around her, and seemed to know my pictures might help her, so she helped me." The daughter on the left hand side tried to prevent publication of the picture, but later, in 1983, there was a public appeal for contributions for Thompson, ill with cancer. A print was bought by the Getty Museum in 1998 for $244,500. (info from Taschen's "Photo Icons").

comment.author: 19191471@N00
comment._content:
Undoubtedly one of THE images in the history of photography.
Definitely an icon.
Great story as well. You can hardly blame the daughter for her attempt to prevent the publication of the image. On the contrary it is a hard picture and it's a good example that in photography there's often an act of aggression involved. I think Dorothea Lange was aware of that.

comment.author: 42349977@N04
comment._content:
When you look at it closely you will notice that the focus is all wrong, the print was probably underexposed (which results in a certain softness) etc. etc. And all that said, the expresion on her face was seen with a compasion which will speak through the ages and will immortalise Lang as well as her subject for times to come. This is what photography is all about. Not about technique, not about lenses and camera's, not about all that material stuff. But only about an eye,connected to a heart and connected to a mind and using the camera as a painters brush or pencil. 

Greetings, Ed

comment.author: 42349977@N04

comment._content: Amazing,Amazing,Amazing,Amazing......

comment.author: 37972705@N05
comment._content: A copy of  this photograph has been in my home since I was a child.  (I am now over 65). My father was a photographer and had this photo and another iconic photograph, of a Vietnamese woman mourning her dead naked baby in her lap, hanging over his work table.  I would see them every time I came to visit him.  The fact that this one was taken by a woman encouraged my eye.  I saw a large version at the ICP in NY when there was a show of Dorothea Lange.  I also carried around "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men" by James Agee with Walker Evans' photos for years. He was another documentarian of the Depression.

comment.author: 37650089@N08
comment._content: This was also one of the photographs that influenced me. For those that are unclear about it, the picture is of a Migrant Mother. Migrant worker usually just means someone that travels to get to where the work is. The key word there is travel. I noticed someone mentioning nationality so I thought you might like to see the Wiki entry and link. This picture was taken during a period referred to as the Dust Bowl. During the Dust bowl the migrant workers were actually displaced farmers from the great plains. Lange was working for the federal government when this was taken, documenting the plight of displaced workers. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dust_Bowl Per Wiki: Dust Bowl conditions fomented an exodus of the displaced from Texas, Oklahoma, and the surrounding Great Plains to adjacent regions. More than 500,000 Americans were left homeless. 356 houses had to be torn down after one storm alone. Many Americans migrated west looking for work. Some residents of the Plains, especially in Kansas and Oklahoma fell ill and died of dust pneumonia or malnutrition. The Dust Bowl exodus was the largest migration in American history within a short period of time. By 1940, 2.5 million people had moved out of the Plains states; of those, 200,000 moved to California. With their land barren and homes seized in foreclosure, many farm families were forced to leave. Migrants left farms in Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Texas, Colorado and New Mexico, but all were generally referred to as "Okies".

comment.author: 13842589@N02
comment._content: I have a print of this on my wall at home.  Only shows on a larger print, but it is the baby that is the sharpest point of focus rather than the mother who is slightly off focus, yet despite this many people only notice the two children and not the baby.  I don't know if the focus point was an accident or deliberate but it certainly makes it a better photo in my opinion as the softness of focuss on the mother gives her a distant removed feel.

comment.author: 8603571@N03
comment._content: Is it not true that two of the children were left out of the photo as it was felt people would not have sympathy for her if they knew she had five kids?

comment.author: 29126868@N07
comment._content: No it isn't. This was a project to document not to create sympathy.  Besides large families was the rule in the 1930s as many children died young, the notion that a family with a lot of kids is a product of today's misguided family values. Only the very wealthy had small families because they could afford the luxury of health.

comment.author: 27822647@N04
comment._content:
No matter how many times I've seen this photo (hundreds) it never fails to effect me. I appreciate what this images says about poverty, strength, weakness, America, The Great depression, family, motherhood, children, dependence, photography and art. 
This image says so much to me.
I am hard pressed to think of another image that evokes the so many emotions in me. This is truly one of the best photographs ever taken.
in my humble opinion, naturally.
